title: The Awakening
dialogue_triumphs: Doctor? Doctor bain't a proper name. Will Chandler be a proper name.
goofs: The apparitions are accompanied by superimposed stars that seem to have been produced on a BBC Micro.

continuity_notes.name: Tinclavic
continuity_notes.description: A material mined by Terileptils on the planet Raaga for the almost exclusive use of the inhabitants of Harkol in the star system of Rifta.

continuity_notes.name: The Malus
continuity_notes.description: The occupant of a Harkol computer-controlled reconnaissance probe that came to Earth in 1643 as the spearhead of an invasion fleet which never followed.

continuity_notes.name: Andrew Verney
continuity_notes.description: Tegan's grandfather, another member of her cursed family.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The main protagonist of Doctor Who, a Time Lord from Gallifrey.
continuity_notes.current_status: Fond of tea, investigating events in Little Hodcombe

continuity_notes.name: Tegan
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's companion, with a seemingly cursed family history.
continuity_notes.current_status: Accompanying the Doctor in Little Hodcombe

continuity_notes.name: Will Chandler
continuity_notes.description: A character from the past that the Doctor promises to take home in the TARDIS.
continuity_notes.current_status: Present in Little Hodcombe, to be returned home by the Doctor

roots: By the Sword Divided and other Civil War drama
Games echoing past evil and psychic projections reminiscent of Sapphire and Steel
links: The Doctor says that he will take Will home in the TARDIS, and this has been accomplished by the start of 'Frontios'.
Tegan's family is also mentioned in 'Logopolis' and 'Arc of Infinity'

locations.name: Little Hodcombe
locations.description: An English village where the events of the episode take place.
locations.current_status: Site of alien influence and historical reenactment in 1984

additional_notes: The episode features a double entendre (or single entendre as noted) where Willow says that if Tegan doesn't change into the May Queen's costume he'll do it for her.
bottom_line: The theme of alien pseudo-diabolist influence on an English village had previously been central to 'The Daemons', but the energy of 'The Awakening' is also its freshness. A beautiful and well-scripted adventure.
